title: How is customer service getting worse? - Quora

response.answer_text: The two main factors boil down to cost and performance measurement. Customer service is expensive, and in most organizations the bulk of the budget goes to revenue generating departments, not cost centers. That means that you have to fight for every dime of budget and what money you have gets spread thin. Hiring the best people means having wages and benefits which compete well with the competition. Making employees skilled requires a talented and dedicated training and quality staff. All these people need sophisticated systems and tools to leverage. These costs are why so many customer service departments got outsourced to India a few years ago, and still are, thought it’s a little less common now. Outsourced CS is simply less expensive. The second factor is measurement. Take the Comcast example. They got a lot of attention a year or so ago because of recordings of their cancellation/retention center’s behavior. My guess is these were not malicious people trying to give a bad experience to customers. This was a call center whose incentives and metrics were not tied to the Customer experience. “You get what you measure, “ is a good rule of thumb. In this case, the agents were likely being measured and evaluated based on how many accounts they saved, or worse, how many customers they lost. That gives incentive to agents to get people to hang up, because that keeps them off your scorecard. The problem in many cases is doing the right thing for a customer is expensive. You can save a lot of money by cutting corners in CS, and people get nice bonuses and promotions for saving money. Here again, companies are “accidentally” incentivising their employees to create a poorer customer experience. They often don’t notice the impact until the bad CS experience starts impacting sales and PR. I don’t think bad CS happens on purpose, but it is an easy trap to fall into.

Just want to throw this out there, Y’all good to disagree. Living in Britain, all you get on the counter of most betting shops these days, I’m afraid, are young girls that just want you to go away so they can get back on their phones. They are paid minimum wage and generally also have minimum interest. I am not like them, I know how to settle bets manually (not just beep the barcode and pay out what it says) and also know how to work out, for example, how many doubles in combinations bets using formulas, etc. I know the all the terminology (including reading form and deconstructing the lingo) so you’re not talking to a brick wall, I’m old school (45yrs) and have old school knowledge; for instance, jusk ask someone behind the counter who matches the description I’ve given and see if they can answer you with ease how many doubles in 8 races (it’s 28 btw). The answer should be virtually instant if they know the formula. They might have to wait ‘until a manager comes back’ because it’s too much for them. Even sometimes the manager doesn’t know either and it’s frustrating, especially when they calculate your winnings wrong (which I had recently) but they didn’t have the ability or authority to correct it. Instead they said I should ring customer services. Why couldn’t they resettle it in the shop? Because not even the manager new how, it’s all done by a head office and the counter staff just beep the barcode and blindly pay out what it says on the screen. I walked out of Ladbrokes over this and have never gone back, but sadly they’re all like it now, it’s down to cost cutting. Minimum wage, minimum interest and knowledge, as I said earlier.
